title: 113_hr3357
content: The "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" aims to assist States in enhancing the knowledge, credentials, compensation, and professional development of early childhood educators in various programs. This includes Head Start Programs, state-funded prekindergarten programs, licensed child care for prekindergarten children, and special education preschools. Grants are authorized for implementation by the Secretary of Education in collaboration with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Each State seeking a grant under the "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" must submit an application to the Secretary of Education, detailing their early childhood professional development system. This system should be developed collaboratively with various stakeholders and include an oversight structure. The State applying for a grant must designate an agency to administer the program and describe how their system provides oversight, professional standards, career advancement, coordination with higher education institutions, articulation agreements, and accessible higher education options. The State applying for a grant must designate an agency to administer the program and describe how their system provides oversight, professional standards, career advancement, coordination with higher education institutions, articulation agreements that recognize prior learning and expertise, more accessible higher education for working learners, support for adult learners from diverse backgrounds, use of workforce data to assess needs, and financing over time. The State must designate an agency to administer the program and outline oversight, professional standards, career advancement, coordination with higher education, articulation agreements, accessible higher education, support for adult learners, workforce data utilization, and financing. The State receiving a grant must use funds for scholarships, support for teachers with non-education degrees, increased compensation for teachers pursuing early childhood education degrees, and professional development opportunities for preschool teachers and assistants. The grant aims to support teachers pursuing early childhood education degrees and provide professional development opportunities for preschool teachers and assistants in various areas of child development, teacher-child interaction, family engagement, and cultural competence. The Act emphasizes that grant funds should supplement, not replace, existing federal, state, and local funds for early childhood educator preparation. States receiving funds must maintain or increase their financial support for activities covered by the Act. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
